content.description:
ESTIMATED INFANT MORTALITY RATES IN WESTERN EUROPE AS A PERCENTAGE OF LIVE BIRTHS

Pre-1750
 1740–1790
 1780–1820

England
 18.7
 16.1
 12.2

France
 25.2
 21.3
 19.5

Spain
 28.1
 27.3
 22.0

Switzerland
 28.3
 23.7
 25.5

Sweden
 NA
 22.5
 18.7

Source: Adapted from Michael Flinn, The European Demographic System, 1500–1820, Johns Hopkins University Press, 1981, table 6.9, p. 92.

The data in the table were derived from an analysis of parish church records in the various countries.
content.question: The overall trend shown in the table had which of the following effects in the period?

choices.label: A significant decrease in the number of children born outside of marriage
A major expansion of child-welfare programs by western European governments
A gradual decrease of family size and an increase in attention to child rearing
A major increase in women's participation in the paid workforce

content.answer: A gradual decrease of family size and an increase in attention to child rearing

skill.text: Skill 5.B: Explain how a historical development or process relates to another historical development or process.
